column1: Dental cavities are holes (or structural damage) in the teeth.
Tooth decay is a common disorder, second only to the common cold.
It usually occurs in children and young adults, but can affect any person.
Tooth decay is a common cause of tooth loss in younger people.
Plaque that is not removed from the teeth turns into a substance called tartar or calculus.
Plaque and tartar irritate the gums, resulting in gingivitis and periodontitis.
Plaque begins to build up on teeth within 20 minutes after eating.
The acids in plaque damage the enamel covering your teeth, and create holes in the tooth (cavities).
Carbohydrates (sugars and starches) increase the risk of tooth decay.
If symptoms occur, they may include: - Tooth pain or achy feeling, particularly after sweet, hot, or cold foods and drinks - Visible pits or holes in the teeth
Dental x-rays may show some cavities before they are visible to the eye.

Treatment may involve: - Fillings - Crowns - Root canals Dentists fill teeth by removing the decayed tooth material with a drill and replacing it with a material such as silver alloy, gold, porcelain, or composite resin.
Many dentists consider silver amalgam (alloy) and gold to be stronger, and these materials are often used on back teeth.
The center of the tooth, including the nerve and blood vessel tissue (pulp), is removed along with decayed portions of the tooth.
Call your dentist if you have a toothache.
X-rays may be taken yearly to detect possible cavity development in high-risk areas of the mouth.
Fluoride is often recommended to protect against dental caries.
People who get fluoride in their drinking water or by taking fluoride supplements have less tooth decay.
